composer 0.19.17 and 0.20.2 added the various cloud wallets to the composer-rest-server docker image, but I would suggest using the latest available docker images of composer-rest-server. 
Also please check the documentation for this cloud wallet impl at 
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer-tools/tree/master/packages/composer-wallet-ibmcos
you need to ensure the environment variable `NODE_CONFIG` is set in order to pick up the correct information.

I've tried composer 0.20.2 (and 0.20.5) with NODE-CONFIG, but I got the same error.
The same NODE-CONFIG works well with local Composer + ClouObjectStore.
An error "lib/cardstore/walletbackedcardstore.js:74:27" in Cloud logs. 
May be I am wrong, but it seems that composer 0.20.2 do not understand what is "composer-wallet-ibmcos".

The docker-compose.yml and the downloadFabric.sh under the fabric-tools/fabric-scripts/hlfv12/ directory have AMD hardcoded. Can this get removed immediately to go back to pick up the architecture?

This was done in the update 10 days ago to get Fabric 1.2.1. The scripts for 1.2.0 worked fine with the varying architectures.

solution to this problem is to upgrade node to version 8.9 or higher but below version 9
the async keyword was added to node only in version 8
steps to upgrade node are documented in https://www.hostingadvice.com/how-to/update-node-js-latest-version/
if using
```
sudo npm cache clean -f
sudo npm install -g n
sudo n 8.9
```
make sure to also run
```
sudo ln -sf /usr/local/n/versions/node/<version>/bin/node /usr/bin/node
```

If we must have LICENSE we should exclude it from the checker as that is looking for the shorter Apache 2 license as found in other files. Alternatively could use LICENSE but put shorter Apache 2 license in it.
Good question. I'm not sure the duplicate LICENSE file adds anything and it was pushed in without a PR. I'll revert the change for now since it's breaking the build.

Stalebot is enabled on the composer repo to address this problem, however it looks like the stalebot config was never added to the composer-tools repo. I'll reopen this issue to fix that. See hyperledger/composer#3855 for background.

You could either download the tar.gz version of the fabric-dev-servers and use tar to unpack that file or you can just install unzip 
```
sudo apt-get install unzip
```
I face the same issue when I try to create admin cards following the tutorial steps.

@Grendel61 I found a way to fix it.

You can try to replace the script 'createPeerAdminCard.sh' under folder 'hlfv11' as below and retry. 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://github.com/hyperledger/composer-tools/blob/e12c84319dbb195dad9ed84fdacf519d43f08641/packages/fabric-dev-servers/fabric-scripts/hlfv11/createPeerAdminCard.sh

Yes. As I wrote above there is only one key/value missing from the Composer Tools for Fabric 1.2 createPeerAdmin.sh. To mitigate the problem add the eventURL key/value as described above to the `fabric-dev-servers/hlfv11/createPeerAdminCard.sh`. This is an effective work around.

eventUrl is has been explicitly removed and a bug in composer 0.19 which had defined it as a mandatory requirement was fixed. If you are using a fabric 1.1 setup you must use Composer 0.19.14. If you are using a fabric 1.2 setup you must use 0.20.0
Thanks for the response. I thought IBM was only at 0.19.5. Earlier I tried 0.20.0 and it failed. I installed 0.19.14 and it is working fine with IBM Cloud.

This is an environmental problem with your set up. With all shells whether a command can be found to be executed depends on whether the directory it exists in is on the PATH. If not then it won't find it. Also if the composer-cli has failed to install maybe due to npm install being run under sudo, but this is not a bug in composer or in the shell script. 

You need to ensure that composer cli is in a directory on your PATH.

Please don't merge this until after Composer 0.20 actually goes out as a release. The install docs point to the version of the fabric-dev-server scripts in master so these will effectively go live from the point they are merged, and the default for Fabric installs will become version 1.2.

I solve it！
just move the code which in fabric-scripts/hlfv11/composer/configtx.yaml to the end of this yaml
the code:
```
Profiles:

    ComposerOrdererGenesis:
        Orderer:
            <<: *OrdererDefaults
            Organizations:
                - *OrdererOrg
        Consortiums:
            ComposerConsortium:
                Organizations:
                    - *Org1
    ComposerChannel:
        Consortium: ComposerConsortium
        Application:
            <<: *ApplicationDefaults
            Organizations:
                - *Org1
```

I think this is the same issue addressed in the pull request. The node-red-composer-contrib@unstable now works with composer v0.19. Unfortunately, it is not labeled the latest build right now so you have to use the @unstable tag (i.e. npm install node-red-contrib-composer@unstable) to install this version instead of just npm install node-red-composer-contrib since that will install the older 0.0.10 version which only works with composer v0.16.x.
Thank you for pointing me to the unstable version. Wasn't sure about how to implement the changes. Now everything is working.

edit: I managed to run it. what i did is i stopped the fabric, teared it down and restarted it, namely:

`~/fabric-tools/stopFabric.sh`
`~/fabric-tools/teardownFabric.sh`
`~/fabric-tools/startFabric.sh`
`~/fabric-tools/createPeerAdminCard.sh`
`cd ~/tutorial-network/`
`composer network install --card PeerAdmin@hlfv1 --archiveFile tutorial-network@0.0.1.bna`
`composer network start --networkName tutorial-network --networkVersion 0.0.1 --networkAdmin admin --networkAdminEnrollSecret adminpw --card PeerAdmin@hlfv1 --file networkadmin.card
`

hope it helps!

Here is how I solved it - with help from the comment by @flibustier on [#3735](https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/issues/3735) and @knagaev on [#65](https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/issues/65) :

I inserted this one line in fabric-tools\hlfv11\startFabric.sh

`export MSYS_NO_PATHCONV=1`

before

```
# Create the channel
docker exec peer0.org1.example.com peer channel create -o orderer.example.com:7050 -c composerchannel -f /etc/hyperledger/configtx/composer-channel.tx
```


After this run 
   .\stopFabric.sh 
   .\startFabric.sh.
Then 'composer network install' and 'composer network start' from the tutorial steps should run correctly.

I made changes to local node-red-contrib-composer code and tested it. 
Catch node in nod-red can capture the error message. I parsed that message based on node-name and used it to submit my transaction if it fails due to mvcc read conflict.

Changes are like:

```
var errorMsg = "Node name :" + node.name + ": " + msg;  //msg is the error thrown internally by the peer
node.error("Catch Error", errorMsg);

```

I am guessing that you are using ubuntu downloaded from the windows store (ie using the Windows Subsystem for Linux), this environment is not supported and unlikely that docker is supported in this environment either. There is an issue https://github.com/hyperledger/composer/issues/65 which is about looking at how support for windows can be achieved, but currently Windows is not supported.
Answered on SO.

I have tested it with a local installation of node-red on the same maschine.

The composer nodes in node-red **only works** if the fabric with the business network is installed on **the same local maschine**.

So there is no remote connection possible, but this would be a nice feature for the future. I think for a prod environment you will not have installed fabric and node-red on the same virtuell maschine or docker host.

What I found is that when I'm sharing `/var/run` of the host for peer0.org1.example.com then my machine became unresponsive. I tried to share only docker.sock in it with `:z` but this command is still failing with permission denied by SELinux:
```
composer network start --card PeerAdmin@hlfv1 --networkAdmin admin --networkAdminEnrollSecret adminpw --archiveFiletutorial-network@0.0.1.bna --file networkadmin.card
```

When I searched more I found more info https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/386767/selinux-and-docker-allow-access-to-x-unix-socket-in-tmp-x11-unix. It's related to sharing X socket but I think that it is somehow related.

When I execute `ausearch -c 'peer' --raw` there is:
```
type=AVC msg=audit(1518602119.703:775): avc:  denied  { connectto } for  pid=9381 comm="peer" path="/run/docker.sock" scontext=system_u:system_r:container_t:s0:c346,c662 tcontext=system_u:system_r:container_runtime_t:s0 tclass=unix_stream_socket permissive=0
```
and what attract my attention is: 
```
scontext=system_u:system_r:container_t:s0:c346,c662 
tcontext=system_u:system_r:container_runtime_t:s0
```

From the stackexchange question that I posted above I added `security_opt` to `docker-compose.yml` and now it looks like it is working. Currently the part of my `docker-compose.yml` looks like this:
```
  peer0.org1.example.com:
    ...
    volumes:
        - /var/run/docker.sock:/host/var/run/docker.sock:z
        - ./:/etc/hyperledger/configtx:z
        - ./crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/peers/peer0.org1.example.com/msp:/etc/hyperledger/peer/msp:z
        - ./crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users:/etc/hyperledger/msp/users:z
    security_opt:
      - label:type:container_runtime_t
    ...
```

Changes that I've made:

 1. Added `:z` at the end of every volume definition for every service.
 2. Instead of mounting the whole `/var/run` from the host to mount only `docker.sock` socket file
 3. Added `security_opt` section to `peer0.org1.example.com` to set the same label as currently defined by default SELinux policy on Fedora.

Do you want from me to create a Pull Request with these changes?

you create card files using the `composer card create` command, or you may have already been provided a card file from somewhere else (eg composer network start). Composer will look for cards in the card store, it doesn't look for card files themselves. You need to import a card file into the card store using `composer card import`

Sorry, I wasn't aware of the required DCO claim. I have updated the commit message accordingly.
@mwittig I think you might still have DCO sign off problems

I have changed the sign-off messages to make DCO robot happy.  ~~In my opinion the robot check is too rigid as it does a case sensitive match for the e-mail address. Moreover it should not check the user name as it maps to my local git config user.name. I can change it at any point in time as it is not part of the Github user profile.~~ I have just digged a little deeper. Now, I understand why DCO robot works as is. Actually, the local part of the e-mail address is case sensitive even though this is discouraged according to section 2.4 of [RFC 5321](https://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc5321.txt). Regarding the user name part [the matter has been recently discussed](https://github.com/probot/dco/issues/43) as part of DCO robot project.
Please give some more time to revise the README and the help node texts.
@mwittig any update on these changes?
@caroline-church Sorry for the delay at my end. I promise to finish up asap. As I am travelling this week I am shooting for early next week.
@mwittig It has been  month since your last update, are you intending to update your pull request?

I am running into the same problem.  In my case it keeps giving the  following error.

@chevdor sorry, but I'm going to reject this PR. This is a _really_ big change and a big change like this should really be covered by an issue or mailing list post and subsequent discussion before a PR is submitted. 

We use Markdown everywhere, not just in this repository. If we were to make this change, we should be consistent and change everywhere that we use Markdown.

We use Markdown in the following places:
- To describe our repositories via README.md, CONTRIBUTING.md files, etc.
- In the GitHub wikis on the main repository.
- Most importantly though, Markdown is used for all of our public website documentation, which is then built via Jekyll.

I had never heard of Asciidoc before you submitted this PR. The includes functionality doesn't seem that useful to warrant such a big change, especially when GitHub doesn't render it without a Chrome specific extension? We seem to be managing OK without it so far.

@caroline-church @dselman FYI, feel free to disagree with me or add your own comments.

Sorry I have to agree with Simon. Needing a chrome plugin to render it on GitHub seems to outweigh benefits and as Simon says we would want to changes this everywhere to make everything consistent. 

I'm also not really understanding what the benefits are?

My comment was probably misleading. In the following, I´ll use adoc for Asciidoc and md for Markdown.

The chrome plugin is NOT required. If you don´t use the plugin, .adoc or .md will behave the same in Github. In general adoc is just superior to md but covers the same minimum set of features. As a matter of fact, renaming a md to adoc does most of the work of switching to adoc.

If you visit https://github.com/chevdor/composer-tools/tree/doc you will see that adoc renders in a similar way than md in a regular browser without any plugin/extension.

If you use adoc however you gain lots of goodies (includes, tocs, ability to include sample code from actual code...). The include feature I mentioned is just one of them and I ensure that you are mistaken if you think this is a small benefit. 

I attach a 'print' of the README.adoc to give you an idea. There are also tons of ways to render adoc to PDF, Ebooks, etc....

[Hyperledger Composer.pdf](https://github.com/hyperledger/composer-tools/files/1393696/Hyperledger.Composer.pdf)

As you mentioned, today, many of the doc file are described in .md files all over the place (readme, contributing, etc...) but since there is no link between them, it is hard for users to find them all and it is obviously hard to maintain. I am seeing lots of discrepancy in the HL and HL-composer doc because doc and code don´t evolve together. The include feature for instance, allows bringing into the doc an actual snippet of code from the original source file. I am not talking about copy/pasting some code snippet into the doc, I am talking about (include...) letting the doc know where to go find the very latest code snippet an include it into the doc. That would benefit the both users and maintainers a lot!

Feel free to reject such a PR but do your due diligence before that.

> I had never heard of Asciidoc before...

It sounds like time to check it out :)

> doesn't seem that useful

Really time to check it out. It would be sad to stop with a "does not seem to..."

> a big change

This is not a big change. But yes, I admit this is a change.

> Needing a chrome plugin to render it on GitHub seems to outweigh benefits

The extension is NOT needed t render on Github. What I wrote is that the extension helps rendering the **include**s. Without the extension, you simply get some similar to what md offers.
Hi @davidkel I would appreciate at least a comment before you close/reject this PR.

I have some sympathy with the issues with MD, however adoc is not the only game in town. Eg readthedocs are big fans of RST: http://ericholscher.com/blog/2016/mar/15/dont-use-markdown-for-technical-docs/

However IMO this would be best handled with a problem statement, discussion at a community call and then a CIP.
